1.verse: There was a man from Ramatayim-Tzofim, in the hills of Efrayim, whose name was Elkanah the son of Yerocham, the son of Elihu, the son of Tochu, the son of Tzuf, from Efrat.

2.verse: He had two wives, one named Hannah and the other P’ninah. P’ninah had children, but Hannah had no children.

3.verse: This man went up from his city every year to worship and sacrifice to ADONAI-Tzva’ot in Shiloh. The two sons of ‘Eli, Hofni and Pinchas, were cohanim of ADONAI there.

4.verse: One day, when Elkanah was sacrificing, he gave a portion of the sacrifice to his wife P’ninah and portions to each of her sons and daughters;

5.verse: but to Hannah he gave a double portion, because he loved Hannah, even though ADONAI had kept her from having children.

6.verse: Her rival taunted her and made her feel bad, because ADONAI had kept her from having children.

7.verse: He did the same every year; and each time she went up to the house of ADONAI, she taunted her so much that she would cry and not eat.

8.verse: Her husband Elkanah said to her, “Hannah, why are you crying, and why aren’t you eating? Why be so sad? Am I not better to you than ten sons?”

9.verse: So Hannah got up after they had finished eating and drinking in Shiloh. ‘Eli the cohen was sitting on his seat by the doorpost of the temple of ADONAI.

10.verse: In deep depression she prayed to ADONAI and cried.

11.verse: Then she took a vow; she said, “ADONAI-Tzva’ot, if you will notice how humiliated your servant is, if you will remember me and not forget your servant but will give your servant a male child, then I will give him to ADONAI for as long as he lives; and no razor will ever come on his head.”

12.verse: She prayed for a long time before ADONAI; and as she did so, ‘Eli was watching her mouth.

13.verse: Hannah was speaking in her heart — her lips moved, but her voice could not be heard — so ‘Eli thought she was drunk.

14.verse: ‘Eli said to her, “How long are you going to stay drunk? Stop drinking your wine!”

15.verse: But Hannah answered, “No, my lord, I am a very unhappy woman. I have not drunk either wine or other strong liquor; rather, I’ve been pouring out my soul before ADONAI.

16.verse: Don’t think of your servant as a worthless woman; because I have been speaking from the depth of my distress and anger.”

17.verse: Then ‘Eli replied, “Go in peace. May the God of Isra’el grant what you have asked of him.”

18.verse: She replied, “May your servant find favor in your sight.” So the woman went on her way, and she ate, and her face was no longer sad.

19.verse: They got up early in the morning and worshipped before ADONAI, then returned and came to their house in Ramah. Elkanah had sexual relations with Hannah his wife, and ADONAI remembered her.

20.verse: She conceived; and in due time she gave birth to a son, whom she named Sh’mu’el, “because I asked ADONAI for him.”

21.verse: The husband, Elkanah, went up with all his household to offer the yearly sacrifice to ADONAI and fulfill his vow.

22.verse: But Hannah did not go up, explaining to her husband, “Not till the child has been weaned. Then I will bring him, so that he can appear before ADONAI and live there forever.”

23.verse: Her husband Elkanah answered her, “Do what seems good to you; stay here until you have weaned him. Only may ADONAI bring about what he said.” So the woman stayed behind and nursed the child, until she weaned him.

24.verse: After weaning him, she took him up with her, along with three young bulls, a bushel of flour and a skin of wine, and brought him to the house of ADONAI in Shiloh, even though he was just a child.

25.verse: After the bull had been slaughtered, the child was brought to ‘Eli;

26.verse: and she said, “My lord, as sure as you live, my lord, I am the woman who stood here near you, praying to ADONAI.

27.verse: I prayed for this child, and ADONAI has granted the request I asked of him.

28.verse: Therefore, I too have loaned him to ADONAI — as long as he lives, he is on loan to ADONAI.” And he prostrated himself there before ADONAI.

1.verse: Then Hannah prayed; she said: “My heart exults in ADONAI! My dignity has been restored by ADONAI! I can gloat over my enemies, because of my joy at your saving me.

2.verse: “No one is as holy as ADONAI, because there is none to compare with you, no rock like our God.

3.verse: “Stop your proud boasting! Don’t let arrogance come from your mouth! For ADONAI is a God of knowledge, and he appraises actions.

4.verse: The bows of the mighty are broken, while the feeble are armed with strength.

5.verse: The well-fed hire themselves for bread, while those who were hungry hunger no more. The barren woman has borne seven, while the mother of many wastes away.

6.verse: “ADONAI kills and makes alive; he brings down to the grave, and he brings up.

7.verse: ADONAI makes poor, and he makes rich; he humbles, and he exalts.

8.verse: He raises the poor from the dust, lifts up the needy from the trash pile; he gives them a place with leaders and assigns them seats of honor. “For the earth’s pillars belong to ADONAI; on them he has placed the world.

9.verse: He will guard the steps of his faithful, but the wicked will be silenced in darkness. For it is not by strength that a person prevails —

10.verse: those who fight ADONAI will be shattered; he will thunder against them in heaven — ADONAI will judge the ends of the earth. He will strengthen his king and enhance the power of his anointed.”

11.verse: Elkanah went home to Ramah, while the child began ministering to ADONAI under the direction of ‘Eli the cohen.

12.verse: ‘Eli’s sons were scoundrels who had no regard for ADONAI.

13.verse: The rule these cohanim followed in dealing with the people was that when anyone offered a sacrifice, the cohen’s servant would come, while the meat was stewing, with a three-pronged fork in his hand.

14.verse: He would stick it in the pan, kettle, caldron or pot; and the cohen would take for himself whatever the fork brought up. This is how they dealt with all the people of Isra’el who came there to Shiloh.

15.verse: The cohen’s servant would actually come before the fat had burned to smoke and say to the man who was sacrificing, “Give the cohen meat he can roast; because he doesn’t want your meat stewed, but raw.”

16.verse: If the man answered, “First let the fat burn to smoke, then take as much as you want,” he would say, “No, give it to me now, or I’ll take it by force.”

17.verse: The sin of these young men was very serious in ADONAI’s view, because they treated offerings made to ADONAI with contempt.

18.verse: But Sh’mu’el ministered in the presence of ADONAI, wearing a linen ritual vest even though he was only a child.

19.verse: Each year his mother would make him a little coat and bring it when she came up with her husband to offer the annual sacrifice.

20.verse: ‘Eli would bless Elkanah and his wife and say, “May ADONAI give you children from this woman because of the boy you have loaned to ADONAI”; then they would go home.

21.verse: So ADONAI took notice of Hannah, and she conceived and bore three more sons and two daughters. Meanwhile, the boy Sh’mu’el grew in the presence of ADONAI.

22.verse: When ‘Eli was very old, he heard about everything his sons were doing to all Isra’el, and that they were having sex with the women doing service at the door of the tent of meeting.

23.verse: He asked them, “Why are you doing things like this? I am hearing bad reports about you from all these people.

24.verse: No, my sons, I don’t hear ADONAI’s people spreading a single good report!

25.verse: If a person commits a sin against another person, the judges can mediate between them. But if a person commits a sin against ADONAI, who can intercede for him?” However, they wouldn’t pay attention to what their father said, because ADONAI had decided to kill them.

26.verse: The child Sh’mu’el kept growing and gaining favor both with ADONAI and with people.

27.verse: A man of God came to ‘Eli and told him, “Here is what ADONAI says: ‘Didn’t I reveal myself to your ancestor’s clan when they were in Egypt, serving as slaves in Pharaoh’s household?

28.verse: Didn’t I choose him out of all the tribes of Isra’el to be my cohen, go up to my altar, burn incense and wear a ritual vest in my presence? Didn’t I assign to your ancestor’s clan all the offerings of the people of Isra’el made by fire?

29.verse: So why are you showing such disrespect for my sacrifices and offerings, which I ordered to be made at my dwelling? Why do you show more honor to your sons than to me, making yourselves fat with the choicest parts of all the offerings of Isra’el my people?’

30.verse: “Therefore ADONAI the God of Isra’el says, ‘I did indeed say that your family and your father’s family would walk in my presence forever.’ But now ADONAI says, ‘Forget it! I respect those who respect me, but those who despise me will meet with contempt.

31.verse: The day is coming when I will break your strength and the strength of your father’s family, so that no one in your family will live to old age.

32.verse: At a time when Isra’el is prospering, you will see a rival in my Dwelling; and never will anyone in your family live to old age.

33.verse: Still, I won’t cut off every one of your men from my altar; because that would make your eyes grow dim, and you would waste away. Nevertheless, all your descendants will die young.

34.verse: Your sign that this will occur will be what happens to your two sons Hofni and Pinchas — they will both die on the same day.

35.verse: I will raise up for myself a faithful cohen who will do what I want and what I intend. I will make his family faithful, and he will serve in the presence of my anointed one forever.

36.verse: Everyone left in your family will come, prostrate himself before him for a silver coin or a loaf of bread, and say, “Please, won’t you give me some work as a cohen, so I can have a scrap of bread to eat?”’”

1.verse: The child Sh’mu’el continued ministering to ADONAI under ‘Eli’s direction. Now, in those days ADONAI rarely spoke, and visions were few.

2.verse: Once, during that period, ‘Eli had gone to bed — his eyes had begun to grow dim, so that it was hard for him to see.

3.verse: The lamp of God had not yet gone out; and Sh’mu’el had lain down to sleep in the sanctuary of ADONAI, where the ark of God was.

4.verse: ADONAI called, “Sh’mu’el!” and he answered, “Here I am.”

5.verse: Then he ran to ‘Eli and said, “Here I am — you called me?” But he said, “I didn’t call you; go back, and lie down.” So he went and lay down.

6.verse: ADONAI called a second time, “Sh’mu’el!” Sh’mu’el got up, went to ‘Eli and said, “Here I am — you called me.” He answered, “I didn’t call, my son; lie down again.”

7.verse: Now Sh’mu’el didn’t yet know ADONAI; the word of ADONAI had not yet been revealed to him.

8.verse: ADONAI called, “Sh’mu’el!” again, a third time. He got up, went to ‘Eli and said, “Here I am — you called me.” At last ‘Eli realized it was ADONAI calling the child.

9.verse: So ‘Eli said to Sh’mu’el, “Go, and lie down. If you are called again, say, ‘Speak, ADONAI; your servant is listening.’ Sh’mu’el went and lay down in his place.

10.verse: ADONAI came and stood, then spoke as at the other times: “Sh’mu’el! Sh’mu’el!” Then Sh’mu’el said, “Speak; your servant is listening.”

11.verse: ADONAI said to Sh’mu’el, “Look! I am going to do something in Isra’el that will make both ears of everyone who hears about it tingle.

12.verse: On that day I will do against ‘Eli everything I have said with regard to his family, from beginning to end.

13.verse: For I have told him that I will execute judgment against his family forever, because of his wickedness in not rebuking his sons, even though he knew that they had brought a curse on themselves.

14.verse: Therefore I have sworn to the family of ‘Eli that the wickedness of ‘Eli’s family will never be atoned for by any sacrifice or offering.”

15.verse: Sh’mu’el lay there until morning; then he opened the doors of the house of ADONAI. But Sh’mu’el was afraid to tell ‘Eli the vision.

16.verse: Then ‘Eli called Sh’mu’el: “Sh’mu’el, my son!” He answered, “Here I am.”

17.verse: ‘Eli said, “What did he say to you? Please, don’t hide it from me; may God do whatever he said and worse, if you hide from me anything he said to you.”

18.verse: So Sh’mu’el told him every word and hid nothing. ‘Eli replied, “It is ADONAI; let him do what seems good to him.”

19.verse: Sh’mu’el kept growing, ADONAI was with him, and he let none of his words fall to the ground.

20.verse: All Isra’el from Dan to Be’er-Sheva became aware that Sh’mu’el had been confirmed as a prophet of ADONAI.

21.verse: ADONAI continued appearing in Shiloh, for ADONAI revealed himself to Sh’mu’el in Shiloh by the word of ADONAI.

1.verse: So the word of Sh’mu’el came to all Isra’el. Isra’el went out to fight against the P’lishtim, setting up camp at Even-‘Ezer, while the P’lishtim camped at Afek.

2.verse: The P’lishtim drew up in battle formation against Isra’el. The battle was fierce, and Isra’el was beaten by the P’lishtim — they killed about four thousand soldiers on the battlefield.

3.verse: When the army had returned to camp, the leaders of Isra’el asked, “Why has ADONAI defeated us today before the P’lishtim? Let’s bring the ark for the covenant of ADONAI from Shiloh to us, so that he will come among us and save us from our enemies.”

4.verse: So the people sent to Shiloh and brought from there the ark for the covenant of ADONAI-Tzva’ot, who is present above the k’ruvim. The two sons of ‘Eli, Hofni and Pinchas, were there with the ark for the covenant of God.

5.verse: When the ark for the covenant of ADONAI entered the camp, all Isra’el gave a mighty shout that resounded through the land.

6.verse: On hearing the shout, the P’lishtim asked, “What does this great shout in the Hebrews’ camp mean?” Then they realized that the ark of ADONAI had arrived in the camp,

7.verse: and the P’lishtim became afraid. They said, “God has entered the camp! We’re lost! There was no such thing yesterday or the day before.

8.verse: We’re lost! Who will rescue us from the power of these mighty gods? These are the gods that completely overthrew the Egyptians in the desert.

9.verse: Be strong; and behave like men, you P’lishtim; so that you won’t become slaves to the Hebrews, as they have been to you. Behave like men, and fight!”

10.verse: The P’lishtim fought, Isra’el was defeated, and every man fled to his tent. It was a terrible slaughter — 30,000 of Isra’el’s foot soldiers fell.

11.verse: Moreover, the ark of God was captured; and the two sons of ‘Eli, Hofni and Pinchas, died.

12.verse: One of the soldiers, a man from Binyamin, ran and came to Shiloh the same day with his clothes torn and earth on his head [as a sign of mourning].

13.verse: As he arrived, ‘Eli was sitting on his seat by the road, watching; because he was trembling with anxiety over the ark of God. When the man entered the city and told the news, the whole city began crying out.

14.verse: On hearing the cries, ‘Eli asked, “What does this uproar mean?” So the man hurried, came to ‘Eli and told him.

15.verse: ‘Eli was ninety-eight years old, and his gaze was fixed, because he was blind.

16.verse: The man said to ‘Eli, “I’m the soldier that came; I escaped today from the battlefield.” He asked, “How did things go, my son?”

17.verse: The one who had come with the news answered, “Isra’el fled before the P’lishtim, and there was a terrible slaughter among the people. Your two sons, Hofni and Pinchas, also are dead; and the ark of God was captured.

18.verse: As soon as he mentioned what had happened to the ark of God, ‘Eli fell backward off his seat next to the gate, broke his neck and died; for he was an old man, and heavy. He had judged Isra’el forty years.

19.verse: His daughter-in-law, Pinchas’s wife, was pregnant and near delivery-time. When she heard the news that the ark of God had been captured and that her father-in-law and husband were dead, she went into abnormal labor, bent over and gave birth.

20.verse: As she was dying, the women standing by her said to her, “Don’t be afraid, because you have given birth to a son.” But she didn’t answer or show any sign of recognition.

21.verse: She named the child I-Khavod [without glory], saying, “The glory has departed from Isra’el”; because the ark of God had been captured, and because of her father-in-law and husband.

22.verse: She said, “The glory of Isra’el has gone into exile, because the ark of God has been captured.”

1.verse: The P’lishtim had captured the ark of God and brought it from Even-‘Ezer to Ashdod.

2.verse: Then the P’lishtim took the ark of God, brought it to the temple of Dagon and set it next to Dagon.

3.verse: But early the next morning, when the people of Ashdod got up, there was Dagon, fallen down with his face to the ground before the ark of ADONAI. They took Dagon and set him in his place again;

4.verse: but early the following morning, when they got up, Dagon was again fallen down with his face to the ground before the ark of ADONAI; this time, the head of Dagon and both hands lay there, severed, on the threshold; all that was left of Dagon was his torso.

5.verse: This is why, to this day, the priests of Dagon and those entering his temple never walk on the threshold of Dagon in Ashdod.

6.verse: ADONAI began oppressing the people of Ashdod; he ravaged them, striking Ashdod and its surrounding area with tumors.

7.verse: When the people of Ashdod came to understand what was happening, they said, “The ark of the God of Isra’el can’t remain with us, because he is oppressing us and our god Dagon.”

8.verse: They summoned all the leaders of the P’lishtim and asked, “What are we to do with the ark of the God of Isra’el?” They answered, “Have the ark of the God of Isra’el carried to Gat.” So they carried the ark of the God of Isra’el to Gat.

9.verse: But after it arrived there, ADONAI oppressed that city, causing terrible panic. He struck the people of the city, great and small alike; tumors broke out on them.

10.verse: Next they sent the ark of God to ‘Ekron; but when the ark of God arrived in ‘Ekron the ‘Ekronim shouted, “Now they’ve brought the ark of the God of Isra’el to us, to kill us and our people!”

11.verse: So they summoned all the leaders of the P’lishtim and said, “Send the ark of the God of Isra’el away! Let it go back to its own place, so that it won’t kill us and our people!” — because death and panic pervaded the whole city; God’s oppression was very heavy there.

12.verse: The people who didn’t die were struck with the tumors; and the city’s cries for help reached the skies.

1.verse: The ark of ADONAI was in the country of the P’lishtim for seven months.

2.verse: The P’lishtim summoned the priests and soothsayers and asked them, “What are we to do with the ark of ADONAI? Tell us how to send it back where it belongs.”

3.verse: They said, “If you do send off the ark of the God of Isra’el, don’t send it back empty, but return it with some sort of guilt offering for him. Then you will be cured, and you will learn why he has not stopped oppressing you.”

4.verse: They asked, “What kind of guilt offering should we send him?” and they replied, “Five gold models of tumors and five gold rats, because that’s how many leaders the P’lishtim have, and you and your leaders all had the same illness.

5.verse: So make models of your tumors and models of your rats that are infesting your land, and show respect to the God of Isra’el. Maybe he will stop oppressing you, your gods and your land.

6.verse: Why be obstinate like the Egyptians and Pharaoh were? When he had done his work among them, didn’t they let the people go? — and they left.

7.verse: Now take and prepare yourselves a new cart and two milk-cows that have never been under a yoke. Harness the cows to the cart, but put their calves back in the shed.

8.verse: Then take the ark of ADONAI and lay it on the cart. In a box next to it, put the gold objects you are sending back to him as a guilt offering. Then send it away to go off by itself,

9.verse: but watch to see if it goes up the road to Beit-Shemesh in its own territory. If it does, he is responsible for this great tragedy; if not, we will know that it is not his oppression which has been over us, but that what has been happening to us has been only by chance.”

10.verse: The men did it. They took two milk-cows, harnessed them to the cart and confined their calves to the shed.

11.verse: Then they put the ark on the cart, along with the box containing the gold rats and the models of their tumors.

12.verse: The cows made straight for the road to Beit-Shemesh and took that route, mooing as they went and turning off neither to the right nor to the left. The leaders of the P’lishtim followed them as far as the border of Beit-Shemesh.

13.verse: The people of Beit-Shemesh were harvesting their wheat in the valley when they looked up and saw the ark. They were so happy to see it!

14.verse: The cart entered the field of Y’hoshua the Beit-Shimshi and stood there by a big rock. They cut up the wood of the cart and offered up the cows as a burnt offering to ADONAI.

15.verse: Then the L’vi’im removed the ark of ADONAI and the box that was with it, which contained the gold objects, and put them on the big rock. That same day the men of Beit-Shemesh offered burnt offerings and sacrifices to ADONAI.

16.verse: Upon seeing this, the five leaders of the P’lishtim returned that day to ‘Ekron.

17.verse: The gold tumors which the P’lishtim sent back as a guilt offering for ADONAI were one each for Ashdod, ‘Azah, Ashkelon, Gat and ‘Ekron;

18.verse: and the gold rats also corresponded to the number of all the cities of the P’lishtim that belonged to the five leaders — fortified cities and country villages. [The rock] is a witness to this day of the great mourning [which resulted from] putting the ark of ADONAI on it in the field of Y’hoshua the Beit-Shimshi;

19.verse: for [ADONAI] struck the people of Beit-Shemesh for looking at the ark of ADONAI. He killed 50,070 of the people; the people mourned because ADONAI had struck them with such a terrible slaughter.

20.verse: The people of Beit-Shemesh asked, “Who can stand before ADONAI, this holy God? To whom can we send it, to get it away from us?”

21.verse: They sent messengers to the people living in Kiryat-Ye‘arim with this message: “The P’lishtim have returned the ark of ADONAI. Come down and bring it back up with you.”

1.verse: So the men of Kiryat-Ye‘arim came and brought back the ark of ADONAI. They took it to the home of Avinadav on the hill and appointed his son El‘azar to guard the ark of ADONAI.

2.verse: From the day that the ark arrived in Kiryat-Ye‘arim a long time elapsed, twenty years; and all the people of Isra’el yearned for ADONAI.

3.verse: Sh’mu’el addressed all the people of Isra’el; he said: “If you are returning to ADONAI with all your heart, then be done with the foreign gods and ‘ashtarot that you have with you, and direct your hearts to ADONAI. If you will serve only him, he will rescue you from the power of the P’lishtim.”

4.verse: So the people of Isra’el banished the ba‘alim and the ‘ashtarot and served only ADONAI.

5.verse: Sh’mu’el said, “Gather all Isra’el to Mitzpah, and I will pray for you to ADONAI.”

6.verse: So they gathered together at Mitzpah, drew water and poured it out before ADONAI, fasted that day, and said there, “We have sinned against ADONAI.” Sh’mu’el began serving as judge over the people of Isra’el at Mitzpah.

7.verse: When the P’lishtim heard that the people of Isra’el had gathered together at Mitzpah, the leaders of the P’lishtim marched up against Isra’el; and when the people of Isra’el heard about this, they were afraid of the P’lishtim.

8.verse: The people of Isra’el said to Sh’mu’el, “Don’t stop crying out to ADONAI our God for us, to save us from the power of the P’lishtim.”

9.verse: Sh’mu’el took a baby lamb and offered it as a whole burnt offering to ADONAI. Then Sh’mu’el cried to ADONAI for Isra’el, and ADONAI answered him.

10.verse: As Sh’mu’el was presenting the burnt offering, the P’lishtim advanced to attack Isra’el. But this time, ADONAI thundered violently over the P’lishtim, throwing them into such confusion that they were struck down before Isra’el.

11.verse: The men of Isra’el went out from Mitzpah, pursuing the P’lishtim and attacking them all the way to Beit-Kar.

12.verse: Sh’mu’el took a stone, placed it between Mitzpah and Shen, and gave it the name Even-‘Ezer [stone of help], explaining, “ADONAI has helped us until now.”

13.verse: Thus the P’lishtim were humbled, so that they no longer entered Isra’el’s territory; and the hand of ADONAI was against the P’lishtim as long as Sh’mu’el lived.

14.verse: The cities between ‘Ekron and Gat which the P’lishtim had captured from Isra’el were restored to Isra’el, and Isra’el rescued all this territory from the power of the P’lishtim. There was also peace between Isra’el and the Emori.

15.verse: Sh’mu’el continued in office as judge of Isra’el as long as he lived.

16.verse: Year by year he would travel in a circuit that included Beit-El, Gilgal and Mitzpah; and in all these places he served as judge over Isra’el.

17.verse: Then he would return to Ramah, because that’s where his home was, and he would judge Isra’el there too. He also built an altar there to ADONAI.

1.verse: When Sh’mu’el grew old, he appointed his sons as judges over Isra’el.

2.verse: His firstborn was named Yo’el, while his second son was named Aviyah; they were judges in Be’er-Sheva.

3.verse: However, his sons did not follow his way of life; they turned off it to pursue riches, so that they would take bribes to distort justice.

4.verse: All the leaders of Isra’el gathered themselves together, approached Sh’mu’el in Ramah

5.verse: and said to him, “Look, you have grown old, and your sons are not following your ways. Now make us a king to judge us like all the nations.”

6.verse: Sh’mu’el was not pleased to hear them say, “Give us a king to judge us”; so he prayed to ADONAI.

7.verse: ADONAI said to Sh’mu’el, “Listen to the people, to everything they say to you; for it is not you they are rejecting; they are rejecting me; they don’t want me to be king over them.

8.verse: They are doing to you exactly what they have been doing to me, from the day I brought them out of Egypt until today, by abandoning me and serving other gods.

9.verse: So do what they say, but give them a sober warning, telling them what kinds of rulings their king will make.”

10.verse: Sh’mu’el reported everything ADONAI had said to the people asking him for a king.

11.verse: He said, “Here is the kind of rulings your king will make: he will draft your sons and assign them to take care of his chariots, be his horsemen and be bodyguards running ahead of his chariots.

12.verse: He will appoint them to serve him as officers in charge of a thousand or of fifty, plowing his fields, gathering his harvest, and making his weapons and the equipment for his chariots.

13.verse: He will take your daughters and have them be perfume-makers, cooks and bakers.

14.verse: He will expropriate your fields, vineyards and olive groves — the very best of them! — and hand them over to his servants.

15.verse: He will take the ten-percent tax of your crops and vineyards and give it to his officers and servants.

16.verse: He will take your male and female servants, your best young men and your donkeys, and make them work for him.

17.verse: He will take the ten-percent tax of your flocks, and you will become his servants.

18.verse: When that happens, you will cry out on account of your king, whom you yourselves chose. But when that happens, ADONAI will not answer you!”

19.verse: However, the people refused to listen to what Sh’mu’el told them, and they said, “No! We want a king over us,

20.verse: so that we can be like all the nations, with our king to judge us, lead us and fight our battles.”

21.verse: Sh’mu’el heard everything the people said and repeated them for ADONAI to hear.

22.verse: ADONAI said to Sh’mu’el, “Do what they ask, and set up a king for them.” So Sh’mu’el told the men of Isra’el, “Each of you, return to his city.”

1.verse: There was a man from Binyamin named Kish the son of Avi’el, the son of Tz’ror, the son of B’khorat, the son of Afiach, the son of a man from Binyamin. He was a man of substance and brave as well.

2.verse: He had a son named Sha’ul who was young and good-looking; among the people of Isra’el there was no one better-looking than he; he stood head and shoulders taller than anyone else in Isra’el.

3.verse: Once the donkeys belonging to Kish Sha’ul’s father got lost. Kish said to his son Sha’ul, “Please take one of the servants with you, go out, and look for the donkeys.”

4.verse: He went through the hills of Efrayim and the territory of Shalishah, but they didn’t find them. Then they went through the territory of Sha‘alim, but they weren’t there. They went through the territory of Binyamin but didn’t find them there either.

5.verse: On reaching the territory of Tzuf, Sha’ul said to his servant with him, “Come, let’s go back; otherwise my father will stop thinking about the donkeys and start worrying about us.”

6.verse: His servant replied, “Here now, there’s a man of God in this city, a man who is highly respected, and everything he says proves true. Let’s go to him; maybe he can tell us something about where we should go.”

7.verse: “But look,” Sha’ul said to his servant, “if we go to the man, what can we bring him? We’ve used up all the bread in our packs, and there’s nothing for us to give the man of God — what do we have left?”

8.verse: The servant replied again to Sha’ul: “See, I have here in my hand a silver quarter-shekel [one-tenth of an ounce]. I will give it to the man of God to tell us which way to go.”

9.verse: (In Isra’el, back in the old days, when someone went to consult God, he would say, “Come, let’s go to the seer”; because a person now called a prophet used to be called a seer.)

10.verse: “Well said,” Sha’ul answered his servant. “Come on, let’s go.” So they went to the city where the man of God was.

11.verse: Ascending the slope to the town they found girls going out to draw water and asked them, “Is the seer here?”

12.verse: The girls answered them, “He’s here, he’s right ahead of you. Hurry now, he just came into the city today, because the people are sacrificing today at the high place.

13.verse: Find him as soon as you enter the city, before he goes up to the high place to eat; because the people won’t eat until he comes and blesses the sacrifice. Afterwards, the ones invited will eat. So go on up, because this is when you will find him.”

14.verse: They went up to the city; and as they entered the city, there was Sh’mu’el coming out toward them to go up to the high place.

15.verse: The day before Sha’ul arrived, ADONAI had given Sh’mu’el a revelation:

16.verse: “Tomorrow at about this time I will send you a man from the territory of Binyamin. You are to anoint him prince over my people Isra’el. He will save my people from the power of the P’lishtim, because I have seen my people’s situation, and their cry of distress has come to me.”

17.verse: When Sh’mu’el saw Sha’ul, ADONAI said to him, “Here is the man I told you about, the one who is going to govern my people.”

18.verse: Sha’ul approached Sh’mu’el in the gateway and said, “Please tell me where the seer’s house is.”

19.verse: Sh’mu’el answered Sha’ul, “I’m the seer. Go up ahead of me to the high place, because you are going to dine with me today. In the morning, I will let you leave; and I will tell you everything that is on your heart.

20.verse: As for your donkeys that got lost three days ago, don’t worry about them; they’ve been found. Now, who is it that all Isra’el wants? Isn’t it you, and all your father’s household?”

21.verse: Sha’ul replied, “I’m only a man from Binyamin, the smallest tribe in Isra’el; and my family is the least important of all the families in the tribe of Binyamin! Why are you saying such a thing to me?”

22.verse: Sh’mu’el took Sha’ul and his servant, brought them into the room and had them sit in the place reserved for the most important of the invited guests, who numbered about thirty persons.

23.verse: Sh’mu’el instructed the cook, “Serve the portion I gave you and told you to set aside.”

24.verse: The cook took the thigh and the adjoining meat and served it to Sha’ul. Sh’mu’el said, “Here, this is what remains! Put it in front of you and eat — it was kept especially for you until the right time; because I said, ‘I have invited the people.’” So Sha’ul dined with Sh’mu’el that day.

25.verse: On coming down from the high place to the city, he spoke with Sha’ul on the roof.

26.verse: They got up early. About daybreak, Sh’mu’el called out to Sha’ul on the roof, “Get up, so I can send you on your way.” Sha’ul got up, and both of them — he and Sh’mu’el — went out.

27.verse: As they were going down, at the edge of the city, Sh’mu’el said to Sha’ul, “Tell the servant to go on ahead”; so the servant went on. “But you, stand still now, because I want you to hear what God has said.”

1.verse: Then Sh’mu’el took a flask of oil he had prepared and poured it on Sha’ul’s head. He kissed him and said, “ADONAI has anointed you to be prince over his inheritance.

2.verse: After you leave me today, you will find two men by Rachel’s Tomb, in the territory of Binyamin at Tzeltzah. They will tell you that the donkeys you were searching for have been found, and that your father has stopped thinking about the donkeys and is anxious over you and asking, ‘What am I to do about my son?’”

3.verse: Go on from there, and you will come to the Oak of Tavor. Three men will meet you there on their way up to God at Beit-El. One of them will be carrying three kids, another three loaves of bread and the third a skin of wine.

4.verse: They will greet you and give you two loaves of bread, which you are to accept from them.

5.verse: After that, you will come to Giv‘ah of God, where the P’lishtim are garrisoned. On arrival at the city there, you will meet a group of prophets coming down from the high place, preceded by lutes, tambourines, flutes and lyres; and they will be prophesying.

6.verse: Then the Spirit of ADONAI will fall on you; you will prophesy with them and be turned into another man!

7.verse: When these signs come over you, just do whatever you feel like doing, because God is with you.

8.verse: Then you are to go down ahead of me to Gilgal, and there I will come down to you to offer burnt offerings and present sacrifices as peace offerings. Wait there seven days, until I come to you and tell you what to do.”

9.verse: As it happened, as soon as he had turned his back to leave Sh’mu’el, God gave him another heart; and all those signs took place that day.

10.verse: When they arrived at the hill, and there in front of him was a group of prophets, the Spirit of God fell on him and he prophesied along with them.

11.verse: When those who knew him from before saw him there, prophesying with the prophets, they asked each other, “What’s happened to Kish’s son? Is Sha’ul a prophet, too?”

12.verse: Someone in the crowd answered, “Must prophets’ fathers be special?” So it became an expression — “Is Sha’ul a prophet, too?”

13.verse: When he had finished prophesying, he arrived at the high place.

14.verse: Sha’ul’s uncle said to him and his servant, “Where did you go?” He answered, “To look for the donkeys. When we saw that they hadn’t been found, we went to Sh’mu’el.”

15.verse: “Tell me, please,” said Sha’ul’s uncle, “what Sh’mu’el said to you.”

16.verse: Sha’ul answered his uncle, “He told us that the donkeys had been found,” but said nothing to him about the matter of his being made king.

17.verse: Sh’mu’el summoned the people to ADONAI in Mitzpah.

18.verse: He said to the people of Isra’el, “Here is what ADONAI the God of Isra’el says: ‘I brought Isra’el up from Egypt. I rescued you from the power of the Egyptians and from the power of all the kingdoms that oppressed you.’

19.verse: But today you have rejected your God, who himself saves you from all your disasters and distress. You have said to him, ‘No! Put a king over us!’ So now, present yourselves before ADONAI by your tribes and families.”

20.verse: So Sh’mu’el had all the tribes come forward, and the tribe of Binyamin was chosen.

21.verse: He had the tribe of Binyamin come forward by families, and the family of the Matri was chosen, and Sha’ul the son of Kish was chosen. But when they looked for him, he couldn’t be found.

22.verse: They asked ADONAI, “Has the man come here?” ADONAI answered, “There he is, hiding, in among the equipment.”

23.verse: They ran and brought him from there, and when he stood among the people he was head and shoulders taller than anyone around.

24.verse: Sh’mu’el said to all the people, “Do you see the man ADONAI has chosen, that there is no one like him among all the people?” Then all the people shouted, “Long live the king!”

25.verse: Sh’mu’el told the people what kinds of rulings should be made in the kingdom, then wrote it on a scroll and set it down before ADONAI. After that, he sent all the people away, everyone to his own home.

26.verse: Sha’ul too went home to Giv‘ah, accompanied by warriors whose hearts God had touched.

27.verse: True, there were some scoundrels who said, “How can this man save us?” They showed him no respect and brought him no gift, but he held his peace.

1.verse: Then Nachash the ‘Amoni came up and set up camp to fight Yavesh-Gil‘ad. All the men of Yavesh said to Nachash, “If you will make a treaty with us, we will be your subjects.”

2.verse: Nachash the ‘Amoni replied, “I’ll do it on this condition: that all your right eyes be gouged out and thus bring disgrace on all of Isra’el.”

3.verse: The leaders of Yavesh answered him, “Give us seven days’ grace to send messengers throughout Isra’el’s territory; then, if no one will rescue us, we will surrender to you.”

4.verse: The messengers came to Giv‘ah, where Sha’ul lived, and said these words in the hearing of the people; and all the people cried out and wept.

5.verse: As this was going on, Sha’ul came, following the oxen out of the field. Sha’ul asked, “What’s wrong with the people to make them cry like that?” They told him what the men from Yavesh had said.

6.verse: The Spirit of God fell on Sha’ul when he heard this; blazing furiously with anger,

7.verse: he seized a pair of oxen and cut them in pieces; then he sent them throughout the territory of Isra’el with messengers saying, “Anyone who doesn’t come and follow Sha’ul and Sh’mu’el, this is what will be done to his oxen!” The fear of ADONAI fell on the people, and they came out with united hearts.

8.verse: He reviewed them in Bezek; there were 300,000 from the people of Isra’el; the men of Y’hudah numbered 30,000.

9.verse: To the messengers that had come they said, “Tell the men of Yavesh-Gil‘ad, ‘Tomorrow, by the time the sun is hot, you will have been rescued.’” The messengers returned and told the men of Yavesh; they were overjoyed.

10.verse: Then the men of Yavesh said [to Nachash], “Tomorrow we will surrender to you, and you can do with us whatever you like.”

11.verse: The next day Sha’ul divided the people into three companies. Then they entered the camp of the ‘Amoni during the morning watch and kept attacking until the heat of the day, until those who remained were so scattered that no two of them were left together.

12.verse: The people said to Sh’mu’el, “Who are the men who said, ‘Is Sha’ul to rule over us?’ Hand them over to us, so we can put them to death.”

13.verse: But Sha’ul said, “No one will be put to death today, because today ADONAI has rescued Isra’el.”

14.verse: Then Sh’mu’el said to the people, “Come, let’s go to Gilgal and inaugurate the kingship there.

15.verse: So all the people went to Gilgal; and there in Gilgal, before ADONAI, they made Sha’ul king. They presented sacrifices as peace offerings before ADONAI there, and there Sha’ul and all the people of Isra’el celebrated with great joy.

1.verse: Sh’mu’el said to all Isra’el, “Here, I have done everything you asked me to do — I have made a king over you.

2.verse: There is the king, walking ahead of you; but I am old and gray-headed. There are my sons with you, and I have walked at your head from when I was a boy until today.

3.verse: So here I am; now is the time to witness against me before ADONAI and before his anointed king. Does any of you think I have taken your ox or donkey, defrauded or oppressed you, or accepted a bribe to deprive you of justice? Tell me, and I will restore it to you.”

4.verse: They answered, “You haven’t defrauded or oppressed us, and you have accepted nothing from anyone.”

5.verse: He said, “ADONAI is witness against you, and his anointed king is witness against you today, that you have found nothing in my hands?” They replied, “He is witness.”

6.verse: Sh’mu’el said to the people, “It was ADONAI who appointed Moshe and Aharon and who brought your ancestors up from the land of Egypt.

7.verse: Now, hold still; because I am going to enter into judgment with you before ADONAI regarding all the righteous acts of ADONAI that he did for you and your ancestors.

8.verse: “After Ya‘akov had entered Egypt, your ancestors cried to ADONAI; and ADONAI sent Moshe and Aharon, who brought your ancestors out of Egypt and had them live here in this place.

9.verse: But they forgot ADONAI their God; so he handed them over to Sisra, commander of the army of Hatzor, and to the P’lishtim, and to the king of Mo’av; and they fought against them.

10.verse: But they cried to ADONAI and said, ‘We sinned by abandoning ADONAI and serving the ba‘alim and ‘ashtarot. But now, if you rescue us from the power of our enemies, we will serve you.’

11.verse: So ADONAI sent Yeruba‘al, B’dan, Yiftach and Sh’mu’el and rescued you from the power of our enemies on every side, and you lived securely.

12.verse: When you saw that Nachash the king of the people of ‘Amon was attacking you, you said to me, “No, we want a king to rule over us” — when ADONAI your God was your king.

13.verse: Now, here’s the king you have chosen, the one you asked for. See, ADONAI has put a king over you.

14.verse: If you will fear ADONAI, serve him, obey what he says and not rebel against ADONAI’s orders — if both you and the king ruling you remain followers of ADONAI your God — [then things will go well for you.]

15.verse: But if you refuse to obey what ADONAI says and rebel against ADONAI’s orders, then ADONAI will oppress both you and your leaders.

16.verse: “Now therefore, hold still; and see the great deed which ADONAI will perform before your very eyes.

17.verse: Now is wheat harvest time, isn’t it? I am going to call on ADONAI to send thunder and rain. Then you will understand and see how wicked from ADONAI’s viewpoint is the thing you have done in asking for a king.”

18.verse: Sh’mu’el called to ADONAI, and ADONAI sent thunder and rain that day. Then all the people became very much afraid of ADONAI and Sh’mu’el.

19.verse: All the people said to Sh’mu’el, “Pray to ADONAI your God for your servants, so that we won’t die; because to all our other sins now we’ve added this evil as well, asking for a king over us.”

20.verse: Sh’mu’el answered the people, “Don’t be afraid. You have indeed done all this evil; yet now, just don’t turn away from following ADONAI; but serve ADONAI with all your heart.

21.verse: Don’t turn to the side; because then you would go after useless things that can neither help nor rescue, they are so futile.

22.verse: For the sake of his great reputation, ADONAI will not abandon his people; because it has pleased ADONAI to make you a people for himself.

23.verse: As for me, far be it from me to sin against ADONAI by ceasing to pray for you! Rather, I will continue instructing you in the good and right way.

24.verse: Only fear ADONAI, and serve him faithfully with all your heart; for think what great things he has done for you!

25.verse: However, if you insist on doing wicked things, you will be swept away — both you and your king!”

1.verse: Sha’ul was — years old when he began his reign, and he had ruled Isra’el for two years,

2.verse: when he chose three thousand of Isra’el’s men. Two thousand of them were with Sha’ul in Mikhmas and in the hills of Beit-El, and a thousand were with Y’honatan in Giv‘at-Binyamin. The rest of the people he sent back to their respective tents.

3.verse: Y’honatan assassinated the governor of the P’lishtim in Geva. The P’lishtim heard of it; so Sha’ul had the shofar sounded throughout the land, saying, “Let the Hebrews hear!”

4.verse: All Isra’el heard that Sha’ul had assassinated the governor of the P’lishtim and thus made Isra’el a stench in the nostrils of the P’lishtim. So the people rallied behind Sha’ul in Gilgal;

5.verse: while the P’lishtim assembled themselves together to make war on Isra’el — 30,000 chariots, 6,000 horsemen and an army as large as the number of sand grains on the seashore. They came up and pitched camp at Mikhmas, east of Beit-Aven.

6.verse: The men of Isra’el saw that their options were limited and that the people felt so hard pressed that they were hiding themselves in caves, thickets, crevices, watchtowers and cisterns;

7.verse: while some of the Hebrews crossed the Yarden to the territory of Gad and Gil‘ad. But Sha’ul was still in Gilgal, where all the people were eager to follow him.

8.verse: He waited seven days, as Sh’mu’el had instructed; but Sh’mu’el didn’t come to Gilgal; so the army began to drift away from him.

9.verse: Sha’ul said, “Bring me the burnt offering and the peace offerings,” and he offered the burnt offering.

10.verse: As soon as he had finished sacrificing the burnt offering, there was Sh’mu’el — he had come, and Sha’ul went out to meet and greet him.

11.verse: Sh’mu’el said, “What have you done?” Sha’ul answered, “I saw that the army was drifting away from me, that you hadn’t come during the time appointed and that the P’lishtim had assembled at Mikhmas.

12.verse: I said, ‘Now the P’lishtim will fall on me at Gilgal, and I haven’t asked the favor of ADONAI,’ so I forced myself and offered the burnt offering.”

13.verse: Sh’mu’el said to Sha’ul, “You did a foolish thing. You didn’t observe the mitzvah of ADONAI, which he gave you. If you had, ADONAI would have set up your kingship over Isra’el forever.

14.verse: But as it is, your kingship will not be established. ADONAI has sought for himself a man after his own heart, and ADONAI has appointed him to be prince over his people, because you did not observe what ADONAI ordered you to do.”

15.verse: Then Sh’mu’el left Gilgal and went up to Giv‘at-Binyamin. Sha’ul counted how many were still there with him, about 600 men.

16.verse: Sha’ul, Y’honatan his son and the men with him took up quarters at Giv‘at-Binyamin, while the P’lishtim remained in camp at Mikhmas.

17.verse: Then raiding parties began coming out from the camp of the P’lishtim, three of them: one group turned toward the road leading to ‘Ofrah in the territory of Shu‘al;

18.verse: another group took the road toward Beit-Horon; and another company took the road toward the desert through the territory overlooking Vadi Tzvo‘im.

19.verse: Now there was no metalsmith to be found anywhere in all the land of Isra’el, because the P’lishtim had said, “We don’t want the Hebrews making themselves swords or spears.”

20.verse: So whenever any of the people of Isra’el wanted to sharpen his hoe, plowshare, axe or pick, he had to go down to the P’lishtim,

21.verse: where the exorbitant prices were two-thirds of a shekel for filing a pick or plowshare and one-third of a shekel for filing an axe or setting an oxgoad in its handle.

22.verse: Thus when the time came to fight, no one in the army of Sha’ul and Y’honatan was equipped with either sword or spear; although Sha’ul and Y’honatan his son did have them.

23.verse: A garrison of the P’lishtim had gone out to the pass of Mikhmas.

1.verse: One day Y’honatan the son of Sha’ul said to the young man carrying his armor, “Come, let’s go across to the garrison of the P’lishtim on the other side. But he didn’t tell his father.

2.verse: Sha’ul was waiting at the far edge of Giv‘ah under the pomegranate tree in Migron; the force with him numbered about 600 men.

3.verse: Achiyah the son of Achituv, I-Khavod’s brother, the son of Pinchas the son of ‘Eli, the cohen of ADONAI in Shiloh, was carrying a ritual vest. No one knew that Y’honatan had gone.

4.verse: Between the passes by which Y’honatan was trying to cross to the garrison of the P’lishtim, there was a rocky spur on one side and another rocky spur on the other side; the name of the one was Botzetz, and of the other, Seneh.

5.verse: The one spur rose up on the north, in front of Mikhmas, and the other on the south, in front of Geva.

6.verse: Y’honatan said to his armor-bearer, “Come on, let’s go across to the garrison of these uncircumcised people. Maybe ADONAI will do something for us, since ADONAI can rescue with a few people as easily as with many.”

7.verse: His armor-bearer replied, “Do everything you think you should; I’m with you, whatever you decide.”

8.verse: Y’honatan said, “Here, we’ll cross over to those men and let them know we’re there.

9.verse: If they say, ‘Wait till we come to you,’ we’ll stand still where we are and not go up to them.

10.verse: But if they say, ‘Come up to us,’ we’ll go on up; and that will be the sign that ADONAI has given us victory over them.”

11.verse: So both of them let their presence be known to the garrison of the P’lishtim; and the P’lishtim said, “Look, some Hebrews coming out of the holes they’ve been hiding in!”

12.verse: Then the men of the garrison said to Y’honatan and his armor-bearer, “Come up to us; we want to show you something.” Y’honatan told his armor-bearer, “Come on up after me, for ADONAI has handed them over to Isra’el.”

13.verse: Y’honatan climbed up, using his hands as well as his feet, with his armor-bearer behind him. The P’lishtim fell before Y’honatan, and his armor-bearer following him finished them off.

14.verse: That first slaughter, of about twenty men, was accomplished by Y’honatan and his armor bearer in a space only half as long as one side of the area a pair of oxen could plow in a day [about 200 yards].

15.verse: There was panic in the field camp among all the P’lishtim; likewise, the garrison and the raiding party panicked. Besides all this, there was an earthquake; thus it grew into panic caused by God.

16.verse: Sha’ul’s men on watch in Giv‘at-Binyamin could see the enemy camp scattering and running in all directions.

17.verse: Sha’ul ordered the forces with him to call the roll and see who was missing. So they called the roll, and found Y’honatan and his armor-bearer not present.

18.verse: Sha’ul told Achiyah, “Bring the ark of God here”; for at that time the ark of God was with the people of Isra’el.

19.verse: But while Sha’ul was talking to the cohen, the uproar in the camp of the P’lishtim continued and kept getting louder. Sha’ul said to the cohen, “Put your hand down.”

20.verse: Sha’ul and the entire force with him assembled and went to battle, but they found the P’lishtim all fighting each other in utter confusion.

21.verse: The Hebrews from the surrounding countryside who had previously been with the P’lishtim and had gone up with them into the camp deserted and went over to Isra’el with Sha’ul and Y’honatan.

22.verse: Likewise, on hearing that the P’lishtim were fleeing, all the men of Isra’el who had hidden themselves in the hills of Efrayim pursued them in battle.

23.verse: So ADONAI saved Isra’el that day, and the battle spread as far as Beit-Aven.

24.verse: Isra’el’s soldiers had been driven to exhaustion that day; but Sha’ul issued this warning to the people: “A curse on any man who eats any food until evening, when I will have finished taking vengeance on my enemies.” So none of the people even tasted food.

25.verse: Now the people came to a forest where there was a honeycomb on the ground.

26.verse: When the people had entered the forest, they saw there the honeycomb with honey dripping out; but no one put his hand to his mouth, because the people feared the oath.

27.verse: But Y’honatan hadn’t heard his father charging the people with the oath, so he put out the end of the staff in his hand, dipped it in the honeycomb and raised it to his mouth; whereupon his eyes lit up.

28.verse: But one of the people said in response, “Your father strictly charged the people with an oath, ‘A curse on any man who eats any food today’; even though the people are fainting with hunger.”

29.verse: Y’honatan answered, “My father has brought trouble to the land. Just look how my eyes have lit up because I tasted a little of this honey.

30.verse: How much greater would the slaughter of the P’lishtim have been today, then, if the people had eaten freely of the spoil they found with their enemies!”

31.verse: That day they had attacked the P’lishtim from Mikhmas to Ayalon; but the people were very exhausted.

32.verse: So the people rushed at the spoil, seizing sheep, cows and calves, slaughtering them on the ground, and eating the flesh with the blood.

33.verse: Sha’ul was told, “Look how the people are sinning against ADONAI, eating with the blood.” He said, “You have not kept faith! Roll a big stone to me immediately!

34.verse: Now,” Sha’ul said, “go around among the people and tell them, ‘Each of you is to bring his cow and his sheep and slaughter them here. Then eat. Don’t sin against ADONAI by eating with the blood.” So each person brought his animal with him that evening and killed it there.

35.verse: Sha’ul erected an altar to ADONAI; it was the first altar that he erected to ADONAI.

36.verse: Sha’ul said, “Let’s go after the P’lishtim by night. We’ll plunder them until dawn; we won’t leave one of them alive.” They answered, “Do whatever seems good to you.” But the cohen said, “Let’s approach God here.”

37.verse: Sha’ul consulted God: “Should I go down in pursuit of the P’lishtim? Will you hand them over to Isra’el?” But he didn’t answer him that day.

38.verse: Sha’ul said, “Come here, all you heads of the people. Think carefully: who has committed this sin today?

39.verse: For, as ADONAI Isra’el’s deliverer lives, even if it proves to be Y’honatan my son, he must be put to death.” But no one among all the people answered him.

40.verse: Then he said to all Isra’el, “You be on one side, and I and Y’honatan my son will be on the other side.” The people replied to Sha’ul, “Do what seems good to you.”

41.verse: Sha’ul said to ADONAI the God of Isra’el, “Who is right?” Y’honatan and Sha’ul were chosen by lot, and the people went free.

42.verse: Sha’ul said, “Cast lots between me and Y’honatan my son.” Y’honatan was chosen.

43.verse: Then Sha’ul said to Y’honatan, “Tell me what you did.” Y’honatan told him, “Yes, I tasted a little honey with the end of the staff in my hand. Here I am; I’m ready to die.”

44.verse: Sha’ul said, “May God do the same to me and more also if you are not put to death, Y’honatan!”

45.verse: But the people said to Sha’ul, “Must Y’honatan die, who has accomplished this great deliverance in Isra’el? Heaven forbid! As ADONAI lives, not one hair of his head will fall to the ground; because he worked with God today!” In this way the people rescued Y’honatan, so that he didn’t die.

46.verse: Then Sha’ul stopped pursuing the P’lishtim, and the P’lishtim returned to their own territory.

47.verse: So Sha’ul took over the rulership of Isra’el. He fought against all his enemies on every side — against Mo’av, the people of ‘Amon, Edom, the kings of Tzovah and the P’lishtim. No matter which way he turned, he defeated them.

48.verse: He demonstrated his strength by attacking ‘Amalek, and he saved Isra’el from the power of those who were plundering them.

49.verse: The sons of Sha’ul were Y’honatan, Yishvi and Malkishua, while the names of his two daughters were these: the name of the older, Merav, and of the younger, Mikhal.

50.verse: Sha’ul’s wife was named Achino‘am the daughter of Achima‘atz; the commander of his army was named Avner the son of Ner, Sha’ul’s uncle.

51.verse: Kish was the father of Sha’ul, and Ner the father of Avner was the son of Avi’el.

52.verse: As long as Sha’ul lived there was bitter war against the P’lishtim. Whenever Sha’ul saw any strong or courageous man, he recruited him into his service.

1.verse: Sh’mu’el said to Sha’ul, “ADONAI sent me to anoint you king over his people, over Isra’el. Now listen to what ADONAI has to say.

2.verse: Here is what ADONAI-Tzva’ot says: ‘I remember what ‘Amalek did to Isra’el, how they fought against Isra’el when they were coming up from Egypt.

3.verse: Now go and attack ‘Amalek, and completely destroy everything they have. Don’t spare them, but kill men and women, children and babies, cows and sheep, camels and donkeys.’”

4.verse: Sha’ul summoned the people and reviewed them in T’la’im — 200,000 foot soldiers, with another 10,000 men from Y’hudah.

5.verse: Sha’ul arrived at the city of ‘Amalek and lay in wait in the valley.

6.verse: Sha’ul said to the Keni, “Go away, withdraw, leave your homes there with the ‘Amaleki. Otherwise, I might destroy you along with them, even though you were kind to all the people of Isra’el when they came out of Egypt. So the Keni went away from among the ‘Amaleki.

7.verse: Then Sha’ul attacked ‘Amalek, starting at Havilah and continuing toward Shur, at the border of Egypt.

8.verse: He took Agag the king of ‘Amalek alive; but he completely destroyed the people, putting them to the sword.

9.verse: However, Sha’ul and the people spared Agag, along with the best of the sheep and cattle, and even the second best, also the lambs, and everything that was good — they weren’t inclined to destroy these things. But everything that was worthless or weak they completely destroyed.

10.verse: Then the word of ADONAI came to Sh’mu’el:

11.verse: “I regret setting up Sha’ul as king, because he has turned back from following me and hasn’t obeyed my orders.” This made Sh’mu’el very sad, so that he cried to ADONAI all night.

12.verse: Sh’mu’el got up early in the morning to meet Sha’ul; however, Sh’mu’el was told, “Sha’ul came to Karmel to set up a monument for himself there, but now he has left and is on his way down to Gilgal.”

13.verse: Sh’mu’el went to Sha’ul; Sha’ul said to him, “May ADONAI bless you! I have done what ADONAI ordered.”

14.verse: But Sh’mu’el answered, “If so, why do I hear sheep bleating and cows mooing?”

15.verse: Sha’ul said, “They brought them from the ‘Amaleki, because the people spared the best of the sheep and cattle to sacrifice to ADONAI your God. But we completely destroyed the rest.”

16.verse: Then Sh’mu’el said to Sha’ul, “Stop! I’m going to tell you what ADONAI said to me last night.” He said, “Speak.”

17.verse: Sh’mu’el then said, “You may be small in your own sight, but you are head of the tribes of Isra’el — ADONAI anointed you king over Isra’el!

18.verse: Now ADONAI sent you on a mission and told you, ‘Go and completely destroy ‘Amalek, those sinners; keep making war on them until they have been exterminated.

19.verse: Why did you seize the spoil instead of paying attention to what ADONAI said? From ADONAI’s viewpoint, you have done an evil thing.”

20.verse: Sha’ul said to Sh’mu’el, “I did too pay attention to what ADONAI said, and I carried out the mission on which ADONAI sent me. I brought back Agag the king of ‘Amalek, and I completely destroyed ‘Amalek.

21.verse: But the people took some of the spoil, the best of the sheep and cattle set aside for destruction, to sacrifice to ADONAI your God in Gilgal.”

22.verse: Sh’mu’el said, “Does ADONAI take as much pleasure in burnt offerings and sacrifices as in obeying what ADONAI says? Surely obeying is better than sacrifice, and heeding orders than the fat of rams.

23.verse: “For rebellion is like the sin of sorcery, stubbornness like the crime of idolatry. Because you have rejected the word of ADONAI, he too has rejected you as king.”

24.verse: Sha’ul said to Sh’mu’el, “I have sinned. I violated the order of ADONAI and your words too, because I was afraid of the people and listened to what they said.

25.verse: Now, please, pardon my sin; and come back with me, so that I can worship ADONAI.”

26.verse: But Sh’mu’el said to Sha’ul, “I will not go back with you, because you have rejected the word of ADONAI, and ADONAI has rejected you as king over Isra’el.”

27.verse: As Sh’mu’el was turning around to leave, he took hold of the hem of his cloak, and it tore.

28.verse: Sh’mu’el said to him, “ADONAI has torn the kingdom of Isra’el away from you today and given it to a fellow countryman of yours who is better than you.

29.verse: Moreover, the Eternal One of Isra’el will not lie or change his mind, because he isn’t a mere human being subject to changing his mind.”

30.verse: Then Sha’ul said, “I have sinned; but in spite of that, please show me respect now before the leaders of my people and before Isra’el by coming back with me, so that I can worship ADONAI your God.”

31.verse: So Sh’mu’el followed Sha’ul back, and Sha’ul worshipped ADONAI.

32.verse: Then Sh’mu’el said, “Bring Agag the king of ‘Amalek here to me. Agag came to him in chains and said, “Without doubt, mine will be a bitter death.”

33.verse: Sh’mu’el said, “Just as your sword has left women childless, so will your mother be left childless among women.” Then Sh’mu’el cut Agag in pieces before ADONAI in Gilgal.

34.verse: Sh’mu’el returned to Ramah, and Sha’ul went up to his house in Giv‘at-Sha’ul.

35.verse: Never again did Sh’mu’el see Sha’ul, until the day he died. But Sh’mu’el grieved over Sha’ul, and ADONAI regretted that he had made Sha’ul king over Isra’el.

1.verse: ADONAI said to Sh’mu’el, “How much longer are you going to go on grieving for Sha’ul, now that I have rejected him as king over Isra’el? Fill your horn with oil, and set out; I will send you to Yishai the Beit-Lachmi, because I have chosen myself a king from among his sons.”

2.verse: Sh’mu’el said, “How can I go? If Sha’ul hears of it, he will have me killed.” ADONAI said, “Take a female cow with you and say, ‘I have come to sacrifice to ADONAI.’

3.verse: Summon Yishai to the sacrifice. I will tell you what to do, and you are to anoint for me the person I point out to you.”

4.verse: Sh’mu’el did what ADONAI said and arrived at Beit-Lechem. The leaders of the city came trembling to meet him and asked, “Are you coming in peace?”

5.verse: He answered, “In peace. I have come to sacrifice to ADONAI. Consecrate yourselves, and come with me to the sacrifice.” He consecrated Yishai and his sons and summoned them to the sacrifice.

6.verse: When they had come, he looked at Eli’av and said, “This has to be ADONAI’s anointed one, here before him.”

7.verse: But ADONAI said to Sh’mu’el, “Don’t pay attention to how he looks or how tall he is, because I have rejected him. ADONAI doesn’t see the way humans see — humans look at the outward appearance, but ADONAI looks at the heart.”

8.verse: Then Yishai called Avinadav and presented him to Sh’mu’el; but he said, “ADONAI hasn’t chosen this one either.”

9.verse: Yishai presented Shammah; again Sh’mu’el said, “ADONAI hasn’t chosen this one either.”

10.verse: Yishai presented seven of his sons to Sh’mu’el; but Sh’mu’el told Yishai, “ADONAI has not chosen these.

11.verse: Are all your sons here?” Sh’mu’el asked Yishai. He replied, “There is still the youngest; he’s out there tending the sheep.” Sh’mu’el said to Yishai, “Send and bring him back, because we won’t sit down to eat until he gets here.”

12.verse: He sent and brought him in. With ruddy cheeks, red hair and bright eyes, he was a good-looking fellow. ADONAI said, “Stand up and anoint him; he’s the one.”

13.verse: Sh’mu’el took the horn of oil and anointed him there in his brothers’ presence. From that day on, the Spirit of ADONAI would fall upon David with power. So Sh’mu’el set out and went to Ramah.

14.verse: Now the Spirit of ADONAI had left Sha’ul; instead, an evil spirit from ADONAI would suddenly come over him.

15.verse: Sha’ul’s servants said to him, “Do you notice that there’s an evil spirit from God that suddenly comes over you?

16.verse: Let our lord now command your servants who are here with you to look for a man who knows how to play the lyre. Then, if the evil spirit from God comes over you, he will play; and it will do you good.”

17.verse: Sha’ul said to his servants, “Find me a man who can play well, and bring him to me.”

18.verse: One of the young men answered, “Here, I’ve seen one of the sons of Yishai the Beit-Lachmi who knows how to play. He’s a brave soldier, he can fight, he chooses his words carefully and he’s pleasant-looking. Besides, ADONAI is with him.”

19.verse: So Sha’ul sent messengers to Yishai saying, “Send me David your son, who is out with the sheep.”

20.verse: Yishai took a donkey, loaded it with bread, a bottle of wine and a kid, and sent them with David his son to Sha’ul.

21.verse: David came to Sha’ul and presented himself to him. Sha’ul took a great liking to him and made him his armor-bearer.

22.verse: Sha’ul sent a message to Yishai: “Please let David stay in my service, because I’m pleased with him.”

23.verse: So it was that whenever the [evil] spirit from God came over Sha’ul, David would take the lyre and play it, with the result that Sha’ul would find relief and feel better, as the evil spirit left him.

1.verse: The P’lishtim rallied their troops for war, assembling at Sokhoh in Y’hudah and setting up camp between Sokhoh and ‘Azekah in Efes-Damim.

2.verse: Sha’ul and the men of Isra’el assembled, set up camp in the Elah Valley and drew up their battle line opposite the P’lishtim.

3.verse: The P’lishtim occupied a position on one hill and Isra’el a position on another hill, with a valley between them.

4.verse: There came out a champion from the camp of the P’lishtim named Golyat, from Gat, who was nine feet nine inches tall.

5.verse: He had a bronze helmet on his head, and he wore a bronze armor plate weighing 120 pounds.

6.verse: He had bronze armor protecting his legs and a bronze javelin between his shoulders.

7.verse: The shaft of his spear was as big as a weaver’s beam, and the iron spearhead weighed fifteen pounds. His shield-bearer went ahead of him.

8.verse: He stood and yelled at the armies of Isra’el, “Why come out and draw up a battle line? I’m a P’lishti, and you are servants of Sha’ul, so choose a man for yourselves, and let him come down to me.

9.verse: If he can fight me and kill me, we’ll be your slaves; but if I beat him and kill him, you will become slaves and serve us.”

10.verse: The P’lishti added, “I challenge Isra’el’s armies today — give me a man, and we’ll fight it out!”

11.verse: When Sha’ul and all Isra’el heard those words of the P’lishti, they were shaken and terrified.

12.verse: Now David was the son of that Efrati from Beit-Lechem in Y’hudah named Yishai. He had eight sons; and in the time of Sha’ul he was old — the years had taken their toll.

13.verse: Yishai’s three oldest sons had followed Sha’ul to battle; the names of his three sons who went to battle were Eli’av the firstborn, next to him Avinadav, and the third Shammah.

14.verse: David was the youngest; the three oldest followed Sha’ul.

15.verse: David went back and forth from Sha’ul to pasture his father’s sheep at Beit-Lechem.

16.verse: Meanwhile, the P’lishti approached with his challenge every morning and evening for forty days.

17.verse: Yishai said to David his son, “Please take your brothers five bushels of this roasted grain and these ten loaves of bread; hurry, and carry them to your brothers at the camp.

18.verse: Also bring these ten cheeses to their field officer. Find out if your brothers are well, and bring back some token from them.

19.verse: Sha’ul and your brothers, with all the army of Isra’el, are in the Elah Valley, fighting the P’lishtim.”

20.verse: David got up early in the morning, left the sheep with a helper, took his load and set out, as Yishai had ordered him. He arrived at the barricade of the camp just as the troops were going out to their battle stations and shouting the war cry.

21.verse: Isra’el and the P’lishtim had set up their battle lines facing each other.

22.verse: David left his equipment in charge of the equipment guard, ran to the troops, went to his brothers and asked if they were well.

23.verse: As he was talking with them, there came the champion, the P’lishti from Gat named Golyat, from the ranks of the P’lishtim, saying the same words as before; and David heard them.

24.verse: When the soldiers from Isra’el saw the man, they all ran away from him, terrified.

25.verse: The soldiers from Isra’el said [to each other], “You saw that man who just came up? He has come to challenge Isra’el. To whoever kills him, the king will give a rich reward; he’ll also give him his daughter and exempt his father’s family from all service and taxes in Isra’el.”

26.verse: David said to the men standing with him, “What reward will be given to the man who kills this P’lishti and removes this disgrace from Isra’el? Who is this uncircumcised P’lishti anyway, that he challenges the armies of the living God?”

27.verse: The people answered with what they had been saying, adding, “That’s what will be done for the man who kills him.”

28.verse: Eli’av his oldest brother heard when David spoke to the men, and it made Eli’av angry at him. He asked, “Why did you come down here? With whom did you leave those few sheep in the desert? I know how conceited you are and how wicked your heart is! You just came down to watch the fighting.”

29.verse: David said, “What have I done now? I only asked a question.”

30.verse: He turned away from him to someone else and asked the same question, and the people gave him the same answer.

31.verse: David’s words were overheard and told to Sha’ul, who summoned him.

32.verse: David said to Sha’ul, “No one should lose heart because of him; your servant will go and fight this P’lishti.”

33.verse: Sha’ul said to David, “You can’t go to fight this P’lishti — you’re just a boy, and he has been a warrior from his youth!”

34.verse: David answered Sha’ul, “Your servant used to guard his father’s sheep. When a lion or a bear would come and grab a lamb from the flock,

35.verse: I would go after it, hit it, and snatch the lamb from its mouth; and if it turned on me, I would catch it by the jaw, smack it and kill it.

36.verse: Your servant has defeated both lions and bears, and this uncircumcised P’lishti will be like one of them, because he has challenged the armies of the living God.”

37.verse: Then David said, “ADONAI, who rescued me from the paw of the lion and from the paw of the bear, will rescue me from the paw of this P’lishti!” Sha’ul said to David, “Go; may ADONAI be with you.”

38.verse: Sha’ul dressed David in his own armor — he put a bronze helmet on his head and gave him armor plate to wear.

39.verse: David buckled his sword on his armor and tried to walk, but he wasn’t used to such equipment. David said to Sha’ul, “I can’t move wearing these things, because I’m not used to them.” So David took them off.

40.verse: Then he took his stick in his hand and picked five smooth stones from the riverbed, putting them in his shepherd’s bag, in his pouch. Then, with his sling in his hand, he approached the P’lishti.

41.verse: The P’lishti, with his shield-bearer ahead of him, came nearer and nearer to David.

42.verse: The P’lishti looked David up and down and had nothing but scorn for what he saw — a boy with ruddy cheeks, red hair and good looks.

43.verse: The P’lishti said to David, “Am I a dog? Is that why you’re coming at me with sticks?” — and the P’lishti cursed David by his god.

44.verse: Then the P’lishti said to David, “Come here to me, so I can give your flesh to the birds in the air and the wild animals.”

45.verse: David answered the P’lishti, “You’re coming at me with a sword, a spear and a javelin. But I’m coming at you in the name of ADONAI-Tzva’ot, the God of the armies of Isra’el, whom you have challenged.

46.verse: Today ADONAI will hand you over to me. I will attack you, lop your head off, and give the carcasses of the army of the P’lishtim to the birds in the air and the animals in the land. Then all the land will know that there is a God in Isra’el,

47.verse: and everyone assembled here will know that ADONAI does not save by sword or spear. For this is ADONAI’s battle, and he will hand you over to us.”

48.verse: When the P’lishti got up, approached and came close to meet David, David hurried and ran toward the army to meet the P’lishti.

49.verse: David put his hand in his bag, took out a stone, and hurled it with his sling. It struck the P’lishti in his forehead and buried itself in his forehead, so that he fell face down on the ground.

50.verse: Thus David defeated the P’lishti with a sling and a stone, striking the P’lishti and killing him; but David had no sword in his hand.

51.verse: Then David ran and stood over the P’lishti, took his sword, drew it out of its sheath, and finished killing him, cutting off his head with it. When the P’lishtim saw that their hero was dead, they fled.

52.verse: The men of Isra’el and Y’hudah got up, shouting, and pursued the P’lishtim all the way to Gat and the gates of ‘Ekron. The wounded P’lishtim fell down all along the road from Sha‘arayim to Gat and ‘Ekron.

53.verse: After chasing the P’lishtim, the army of Isra’el returned and plundered their camp.

54.verse: David took the head of the P’lishti and brought it to Yerushalayim, but he put the armor of the P’lishti in his tent.

55.verse: When Sha’ul saw David go out to fight the P’lishti, he said to Avner, the army’s commander, “Avner, whose son is this boy?” “By your life, O king,” Avner replied, “I don’t know.”

56.verse: The king said, “Find out whose son this boy is.”

57.verse: As David returned from killing the P’lishti, Avner took him and brought him to Sha’ul with the head of the P’lishti in his hand.

58.verse: Sha’ul asked him, “Young man, whose son are you?” David answered, “I am the son of your servant Yishai the Beit-Lachmi.”

1.verse: By the time David had finished speaking to Sha’ul, Y’honatan found himself inwardly drawn by David’s character, so that Y’honatan loved him as he did himself.

2.verse: That day, Sha’ul took David into his service and would not let him go home to his father’s house any more.

3.verse: Y’honatan made a covenant with David, because he loved him as he did himself.

4.verse: Y’honatan removed the cloak he was wearing and gave it to David, his armor too, including his sword, bow and belt.

5.verse: David would go out, and no matter where Sha’ul sent him, he was successful. Sha’ul put him in charge of the fighting men; all the people thought it good, and so did Sha’ul’s servants.

6.verse: As David and the others were returning from the slaughter of the P’lishti, the women came out of all the cities of Isra’el to meet King Sha’ul, singing and dancing joyfully with tambourines and three-stringed instruments.

7.verse: In their merrymaking the women sang, “Sha’ul has killed his thousands, but David his tens of thousands.”

8.verse: Sha’ul became very angry, because this song displeased him. He said, “They give David credit for tens of thousands, but me they give credit for only thousands. Now all he lacks is the kingdom!”

9.verse: From that day on, Sha’ul viewed David with suspicion.

10.verse: The following day an evil spirit from God came powerfully over Sha’ul, so that he fell into a frenzy in the house. David was there, playing his lyre as on other occasions. This time Sha’ul had his spear in his hand;

11.verse: and he threw the spear, thinking, “I will pin David to the wall!” But David dodged out of the way twice.

12.verse: Sha’ul became afraid of David, because ADONAI was with him and had left Sha’ul.

13.verse: Therefore Sha’ul put him at a distance from himself by making him commander over a thousand; his goings and comings became public knowledge.

14.verse: David had great success in all his ways; ADONAI was with him.

15.verse: When Sha’ul saw how very successful he was, he became afraid of him.

16.verse: But all Isra’el and Y’hudah loved David, because they knew about all his campaigns.

17.verse: Sha’ul said to David, “Here is my older daughter Merav. I will give her to you as your wife; only continue displaying your courage for me, and fight ADONAI’s battles.” Sha’ul was thinking, “I don’t dare touch him, so let the P’lishtim do away with him.”

18.verse: David’s response to Sha’ul was, “Who am I, that I should become the king’s son-in-law? I don’t have any kind of a life, and my father’s family has no rank in Isra’el.”

19.verse: However, when it was time for Merav Sha’ul’s daughter to be given to David, she was given to Adri’el the Mecholati as his wife.

20.verse: But Mikhal Sha’ul’s daughter fell in love with David. They told Sha’ul, and it pleased him.

21.verse: Sha’ul said, “I’ll give her to him, so that she can entrap him, and the P’lishtim can do away with him.” So Sha’ul said to David, “Today you will become my son-in-law through the second [daughter].”

22.verse: Sha’ul ordered his servants to speak privately with David and say, “Look, the king is pleased with you, and all his servants like you; so become the king’s son-in-law.”

23.verse: Sha’ul’s servants said this to David; but David replied, “Do you think being the king’s son-in-law is something to be treated so casually, given that I’m a poor man without social standing?”

24.verse: Sha’ul’s servants reported back to him how David had responded.

25.verse: Sha’ul said, “Here’s what you are to say to David: ‘The king doesn’t want any dowry; he wants a hundred foreskins of the P’lishtim, so that he can have vengeance on the king’s enemies.” For Sha’ul was hoping to have David killed by the P’lishtim.

26.verse: When his servants said these words to David, it pleased David to become the king’s son-in-law. Even before the time [for him to be married],

27.verse: David got up and set out, he and his men, and killed two hundred men of the P’lishtim. He brought their foreskins and gave all of them to the king in order to become the king’s son-in-law. Then Sha’ul gave him Mikhal his daughter as his wife.

28.verse: Sha’ul saw and understood that ADONAI was with David and that Mikhal Sha’ul’s daughter loved him.

29.verse: This only made Sha’ul the more afraid of David, so that Sha’ul became David’s enemy for the rest of his life.

30.verse: The leaders of the P’lishtim would attack; but whenever they attacked, David was more successful than any of Sha’ul’s servants; so that David acquired a great reputation.

1.verse: Sha’ul told Y’honatan his son and all his servants that they should have David killed. But because Y’honatan was very fond of David,

2.verse: he told him, “My father Sha’ul is out to have you killed. Therefore you must be very cautious tomorrow morning. Find a well-concealed place to hide in.

3.verse: I will go out and stand next to my father in the countryside where you’re hiding. I will talk with my father about you; and if I learn anything, I’ll tell you.”
